awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2023 Chromosome Dynamics Gordon Research Seminar
awd_abstract_narration:
The award will provide support for early career scientists, including graduate students and post-doctoral researchers, to attend the 2023 Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Chromosome Dynamics in Lucca, Italy, just prior to the corresponding Gordon Research Conference (GRC). These conferences bring together diverse scientists who study chromosome biology from different disciplinary perspectives (molecular and cellular biology, genetics, genomics, biophysics, biochemistry, evolutionary biology, among others). The research advances foundational knowledge about genome architecture, dynamics, and function, which has implications for various sectors of the bioeconomy, including biotechnology, agriculture, and medicine. The GRS serves as a forum for junior US and international scientists to present unpublished research, exchange ideas and resources, benefit from career mentoring, and build their professional network. The GRS is organized and co-chaired by a post-doctoral scholar, which serves as a notable career development experience. 

The GRS and associated GRC will advance research on the mechanisms of formation, repair, and maintenance of chromosomes from molecular to organism scales and through evolution. Investigators from around the world will have the opportunity to discuss pioneering ideas and emerging technologies in the field and potentially launch new collaborations. The GRS in particular will facilitate training and professional development of a diverse group of scientists in the field of chromosome biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
My recent experience as chair of the Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Chromosome Dynamics greatly expanded my view of the inequities that exist on a global scale. As chair, I was responsible for creating the program and fundraising to support the cost of the conference. Due to the small size of the Gordon conferences, they are both the most professional rewarding and the most exclusive toward historically marginalized people. Using funds from the NSF, I made it a personal challenge to create the most inclusive Gordon conference possible. I advertised widely on twitter and email and raised over $12,000 to fund the travel and registration for five trainees who would otherwise not be able to attend the conference. All of these trainees were from historically excluded countries, some facing serious travel and financial restrictions that greatly increased their barrier of entry. I am very proud that one of these attendees I supported has now been elected to chair the next GRS in 2025, which will be an amazing opportunity for her career advancement. In addition to fundraising, I also was extremely meticulous when selecting the 14 speakers for the conference. In addition to selection based on abstract quality, I also ensured that half of the speakers were women and 5 were from a historically underrepresented racial minority. I also made sure not to select based on native English language speaking abilities. 

 

In summary, the NSF grant was used to dramatically lower the barrier of attending the GRS on Chromosome Dynamics for a select group of historically marginalized trainees. At the meeting, these trainees were able to engage in scholarship with other trainees through sharing of their research progress in the format of oral and poster presentations. The trainees also interacted with mentors who are leaders of the field both within and outside of academia, which helped them gain access to career advice to jumpstart their early careers.
